Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Mechanisms of microbe-mediated plant species coexistence across spatial and temporal scales
Award.AbstractNarration:
Interactions between plants and their unseen microbial associates are ubiquitous in nature, yet their role in driving the diversity and coexistence of plants is not well understood. One way microbes could enhance plant coexistence is through negative plant-soil feedbacks: Plants often accumulate species-specific pathogens in their roots and soils. As a plant species increases in number, so do their pathogens, which limits unrestricted growth and can be a mechanism to allow coexistence of many plant species. This mechanism has been tested in the greenhouse, but we have little knowledge of its importance in nature. This research aims to investigate plant-soil feedbacks and its consequences for competition and coexistence between plant species by first testing it in the greenhouse, and then examining it in a field experiment. New projects that focus on culturing and sequencing the fungal associates of plants in the field and greenhouse experiments will answer questions such as: Which microbes are most important in plant-soil feedbacks? What are their effects on plant hosts? Are these effects dependent on climate? The results of these investigations will shed light on the drivers of coexistence in two foundational arid-land grasses, and will be shared with land managers to improve stewardship. This research will also provide research opportunities for undergraduate students, as well as increase public understanding of arid-land ecosystems via summer camp experiences for school children and outreach.
Substantial theory and mechanistic models predict that plant-microbe interactions contribute to species coexistence, and greenhouse experiments show considerable evidence of microbe-driven plant-soil feedback (PSF). However, field tests of the role of PSF in long term vegetation dynamics are critical to determining the relative importance of PSF compared to other mechanisms of coexistence, such as spatial abiotic niche variation, operating in nature. Dissertation work fills that gap by linking the strengths of PSF (measured in field experiments) to decades-long variation in the stability of coexistence. Proposed improvements will resolve questions that have arisen from dissertation work by characterizing the belowground mechanisms of PSF using next-generation sequencing methods and targeted greenhouse inoculation of fungal cultures. Results will advance knowledge by increasing the ability to scale plant-microbe interactions from the greenhouse to the field, resolving the degree to which fungal community composition explains vegetation dynamics over spatial and temporal scales, and determining the ecological roles of a poorly understood group of fungi (dark septate endophytes), which has the potential to revolutionize current paradigms on how plants respond to abiotic stress.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Interactions and feedbacks between plant hosts and their root-associated microbes have gained recognition as a potentially important component in regulating coexistence and competition dynamics of plant communities across time and space. However, we know little about how well greenhouse experiments approximate and explain plant communities in nature, because we often do not know the dynamics of the microbial communities underlying such experiments. In this project, our goals were to: 1) test whether plant-soil microbial feedbacks can explain long term abundance dynamics of plant communities in the field, 2) uncover the microbial communities underlying greenhouse and field plant-soil feedback experiments, and compare those to naturally-occurring communities, and 3) investigate the potential of root-associated fungi in the Ascomycota, an under-studied group, to regulate plant growth under drought conditions.

From the field study, we found that plant-soil feedbacks measured in a field experiment correlated with local long term plant abundance dynamics. In patches where relative abundances of the two dominant plant species were stable through time, we found negative plant-soil feedbacks, known to stabilize coexistence between competitors. In patches where relative abundances of the two dominant plants fluctuated through time, we found positive feedbacks that are known to de-stabilize coexistence. This is the first study to demonstrate that plant-soil feedbacks can be directly linked to long term plant community dynamics in the field.

To uncover the microbial dynamics underlying the field experiment and a previous greenhouse feedback experiment using the same plant species, we sequenced root samples from plants in these experiments as well as from the microbial inoculation ‘sources’ for these experiments: seven-year field monocultures and naturally-established plants. We found that despite studies sharing a common, species-poor, core communities, root fungal community composition differed strongly among study types. Plants from experiments, which were younger and more highly manipulated, had higher diversity in their fungal communities compared to older and less manipulated plants. Our results confirmed the efficacy of a common design that uses experimental inoculations of host-specific microbial communities to test effects on different species. However, these inoculations did not establish communities that reflected the original relative abundance structure of the source communities. Our study showed that despite qualitatively similar aboveground plant-soil feedback outcomes in the greenhouse and the field experiments, belowground microbial mechanisms may be differ in the two study conditions. Finally, our work also established methods for teasing out specific fungal taxa that can be used to directly predict plant-soil feedbacks in experiments, and allow for greater ability to generalize experimental results to natural conditions.

From the field study, we established a culture library of fungal strains and tested 10 candidates in a greenhouse experiment that investigated the effects of those fungi on host plants under ambient and drought conditions. Fungal candidates were chosen for their observed specific associations to each host plant, or to patch plant abundance dynamics. We found that drought altered the effects of fungi on host plant growth and trait expression. In particular, a few strains, such as Monosporascus cannonballus, increased root biomass and length relative to control only under drought conditions. Our study focused on root fungal associates in the Ascomycota. This group of fungi are common plant endophytes in dryland ecosystems, but are relatively understudied. Our work provides new insights into the potential of plant-microbe interactions to mitigate stressful environmental conditions.

Broader impacts

This project has provided research experience for 4 undergraduate research assistants (2 male, 2 female) and two technicians in this project, and resulted in 2 undergraduate independent research projects (honors theses; male, female). In addition, we have implemented a one hour teaching unit for elementary school children about the importance of soil micro-organisms in preventing erosion and enhancing plant nutrient acquisition. The teaching unit also explains and stresses the importance of the scientific method. The unit is now under revision and will be made available publicly via a science education website. Finally, our work has generated new knowledge of the capacity of root-associated fungi to mitigate the effects of drought on plant hosts in a dryland ecosystem. Future work on the effects of decreasing mean and increasing variation on plant-fungal interactions in dryland ecosystems will illuminate the role of soil microbial communities in response to global climate change.
